bibl.title: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, October 28, 1939

div1.p: Hutchison informs Hench that his plans for a yellow fever speech have been postponed from commencement to November 1940 (Founder's Day), to dedicate the Lazear Chemistry Building. An autograph note by Hench lists possible speakers.

div1.head: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, October 28, 1939

opener.dateline:
THE PRESIDENT'S OFFICE
WASHINGTON AND JEFFERSON COLLEGE
WASHINGTON, PENNSYLVANIA
October 28, 1939

div1.p:
I am distressed to learn that you have been
ill. I can imagine that it took a good deal of strength
out of you and that it has taken you a long time to
come back. I hope that very soon you will find yourself
back to normal and completely recovered.

I am glad you received the congratulations on
the Jewish New Year. There is something about that
holiday that always reminds me of you and so I always
try to send you my affectionate regards. I do believe
firmly in interracial equality, and I think that on one's
New Year it is the time for amenities from one race to
another!

I think that the Medical Founders' Day of which
we have been talking for years must come to pass a year
from now. We hope to have the Chemistry Building finished
at that time. We have decided to name the building
“The Lazear Chemistry Building”. It would therefore be
most fitting that our long talked of plan should be
carried out a year from now on Founders' Day, probably
about November ninth or tenth of 1940. The boys are
already at work on “Yellow Jack” which they will give
this year and have ready to give again then. Because of
the dedication of this building, I believe that this
medical program will even be more effective than it would
have been at the time we originally proposed it.

Now, as a first step on this proposition, we
need to spot the key man for speaker. We use two
speakers on Founders' Day and we really need to spot two
key men as speakers. Both should be along medical lines.
One might be a medical man himself, and the other one
might be some kind of a specialist on medicine who is
not a medical man or physician. Please turn this over
in your mind now and let me know who you think would be
the most attractive and draw the most attention if he
should come as our speaker on that occasion. I am
presuming, right from the beginning, that we cannot get
Lord Dawson of Penn. It is too bad that Sidney Howard,
the writer of Yellow Jack, and one of our honorary alumni,
was killed this summer. Perhaps you saw that in the papers.

div1.p:
Another question which occurs to me is this -
how can we present most effectively and dramatize some-
what the story of Moran and Kissinger on which stories
you are working at the present time? My present
thought is that you ought to give that at the dinner in
the evening.

Give my love to Mary. I am anxious to see her
and you and all of the family. I am still watching for
a chance to get up there in order to accomplish this
and also to take another examination.

In regard to Harriet, I have news which is both
good and bad. She has steadily improved and August
and September saw her almost completely back in shape
and going one hundred per cent. However, this past three
weeks she has again been having bad headaches, some
suffering, and we are going back to further examination.
This will wait until I come back from California.

I am leaving for California tomorrow, flying
both ways. The purpose is a short, snappy financial
campaign at Los Angeles. I will only be there about two
days. En route, I will have a day with my father at
Garden City and a day with Jim in Denver on which same
day we will have a dinner for the Rocky Mountain alumni
of Washington and Jefferson College.

After that trip, I hope we can get Harriet
straightened out and then I hope I can get to Rochester
before you go to Florida.
Our love to all of you, and keep well.
div1.closer:
Affectionately yours, Ralph Cooper Hutchison H
Doctor Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
